Review Recent advances and perspectives in cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction, and N2 fixation Wanjun Sun a c Jiayu Zhu a Meiyu Zhang a Xiangyu Meng a Mengxue Chen a Yu Feng a Xinlong Chen a Yong Ding a b * a State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalysis of Gansu Province, and College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalysis of Gansu Province College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Lanzhou University Lanzhou Gansu 730000 China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalysis of Gansu Province, and College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China b State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou Gansu 730000 China State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China c Department of Chemistry and Life Science, Gansu Normal University for Nationalities, Hezuo 747000, China Department of Chemistry and Life Science Gansu Normal University for Nationalities Hezuo 747000 China Department of Chemistry and Life Science, Gansu Normal University for Nationalities, Hezuo 747000, China * Corresponding author Solar-driven conversion of carbon dioxide, water and nitrogen into high value-added fuels (e.g. H2, CO, CH4, CH3OH, NH3 and so on) is regarded as an environmental-friendly and ideal route for relieving the greenhouse gas effect and countering energy crisis, which is an attractive and challenging topic. Hence, various types of photocatalysts have been developed successively to meet the requirements of these photocatalysis. Among them, cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts emerge as one of the most promising photocatalysts that open up alluring vistas in the field of solar-to-fuels conversion, which can effectively enhance photocatalytic efficiency by extending light absorption range, promoting charge separation, providing active sites, and lowering reaction barrier. In this review, we first present the working principles of cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction, and N2 fixation. Second, five efficient strategies including surface modification, morphology modulation, crystallinity controlling, crystal engineering and doping, are discussed for improving the photocatalytic performance with different types cobalt-based catalysts (cobalt nanoparticles and single atom, oxides, sulfides, phosphides, MOFs, COFs, LDHs, carbide, and nitrides). Third, we outline the applications for the state-of-the-art photocatalytic CO2 reduction and water splitting, and nitrogen fixation over cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts. Finally, the central challenges and possible improvements of cobalt-based photocatalysis in the future are presented. The purpose of this review is to summarize the past experience and lessons, and provide reference for the further development of cobalt-based photocatalysis technology. Graphical Abstract This review provides a systematic summary on recent achievements of cobalt-based heterogeneous photocatalysts in fields of photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction, and N2 fixation. Furthermore, some challenges and perspectives are discussed. Keywords Photocatalysis Cobalt based heterogeneous catalyst Water splitting Carbon dioxide reduction Nitrogen fixation 1 Introduction The ever-growing concerns on energy shortage and climate changes have motivated widespread research efforts to explore renewable energy alternatives by sustainable technologies. Inspired by nature, artificial photosynthesis system has been elaborately devised to convert the H2O, CO2 and N2 into energy-rich products, such as H2, CO, CH4, CH3OH, NH3 and so on [1–5]. However, the water splitting, the reduction of CO2 and N2 include the transfer of multiple electrons and high energy barriers, thus leading to slow reaction kinetics [6–9]. Consequently, the development of cost-effective catalysts to facilitate these reactions is desirable. In 1972, the landmark work of photoelectrocatalytic water splitting over TiO2 under ultraviolet irradiation was reported by Fujishima et al. [10], revealing the feasible conversion of solar energy into chemical energy. In 1977, Schrauzer et al. [11] first demonstrated that Fe-doped TiO2 as a proof-of-concept to convert N2 into NH3 under ultraviolet light irradiation. Two years later, Fujishima et al. [12] achieved the generation of HCOOH, HCHO, and CH3OH by direct reduction of CO2 over GaP, ZnO, CdS, GaP and SiC. Following these pioneering works on photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation, increasing attention have been attracted to this field, and many exciting progresses have been made in recent years. However, the state-of-the-art efficiency of solar-to-chemical energy conversion is still behind the requirement for practical applications. There are some reviews on cobalt-based electrocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) or N2 fixation [13–15]. Nevertheless, there are still few comprehensive reviews on cobalt cocatalysts for photocatalytic reactions [16]. Here, we present a timely review of the recent progress on cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation for solar fuel generation. We first elaborately illustrate the basic reaction mechanism of water splitting, CO2RR and N2 fixation. Meanwhile, the design strategy for cobalt-based catalysts on morphology or crystallinity controlling, doping, crystal facet engineering, surface modification and other strategies are systematically commented. Then summarize recent progress in the development of cobalt-based photocatalysts towards these reactions. Finally, we discuss the challenges and perspectives for the future development of cobalt-based catalysts in designing novel, efficient and stable cobalt-based photocatalysts for applications and opportunities (Fig. 1 ). This review provides a reference and guidance to inspire more innovative works on the design and fabrication of efficient cobalt-based photocatalysts for sustained solar energy conversion. 2 Fundamentals of photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation Usually in the photocatalytic processes, solar energy conversion system is closely related to the following three key steps (Fig. 2 ) [17–20]: (1) improving the absorption of solar light by catalysts; (2) promoting the separation and transfer of photogenerated charges; (3) and improving the utilization of photogenerated charges. Among them, interface chemical reaction is usually considered as a crucial step in photocatalytic reaction process, which primarily involves the charge transfer and redox reaction at the interface, and directly influences photocatalytic reaction efficiency. Here, in the surface of these catalytic reactions, CO2 is reduced to value-added fuels and chemicals, and water is reduced by electrons to produce H2, while holes oxidize H2O to form O2. In addition, the N2 can be activated and converted into NH3 by electrons. According to the final products, these photocatalytic reactions have different reduction potential accordingly as shown in Table 1 [21–24] Based on the above mentioned discussion, the application of a cobalt-based catalyst can meet the requirements (2) and (3) points. Introducing appropriate catalysts to the photocatalytic system can not only extend the spectral absorption range to a certain degree, but also act as active sites, boosting the separation of charges and their utilization efficiency, and reducing the activation energy or overpotential of semiconductor-surface chemical reactions [25–27]. In addition, some of visible light responsive semiconductors are likely oxidized by photogenerated holes and causing their self-decomposition, so introducing cocatalysts can inhibit photocorrosion and enhance photostability of the photocatalysts by timely using of the electron-hole pairs to participate in the reaction. It is well recognized that a series of factors, including the loading amount, the particle size, shape, phase, dispersity, structure and chemical composition, ultimately influence the activities of catalysts when combining with semiconductors or photosensitizers for photocatalytic performance [28]. Therefore, the earth-abundant cobalt-based catalysts with their structural stability, facile preparation, and high performance are versatile functions for photocatalytic activity, which open up alluring vistas in the areas of solar-to-fuels conversion from the considerations of enhancing light harvesting, accelerating separation and transfering of photo-triggered charges, and boosting surface redox reactions. Generally, the photon energy (sourced from the freely available solar energy) is converted to chemical energy with a concomitant largely positive change in the Gibbs free energy (ΔG 0 = +237 kJ mol−1) for water splitting into H2 and O2. This uphill reaction is similar to the photosynthesis of green plants, and thus considered as an artificial photosynthesis, which is an attractive and challenging subject in the field of new energy sources [29,30]. In addition, as one of the half reactions in water splitting, water oxidation usually involves the four electrons/protons transfer processes with O–H bond cleavage and O–O bond formation, and sluggish O–O bond formation kinetics with a high-energy-barrier, which is considered as the bottleneck for both natural and artificial photosynthesis [31–35]. Furthermore, oxidizing water to oxygen can supply the electrons and protons that are necessary to convert water or CO2 into hydrogen or transportable liquid fuels [36,37]. NH3, as a vital component of all chemical processes and life, is a far-reaching carbon-free and environmentally friendly energy carrier with no CO2 emission at final utilization [38]. Although the fixation of N2 to NH3 is thermodynamically accessible (N2(g) + 3H2(g) = 2NH3(g), ΔH 298 K = ‒92 kJ mol−1), this reaction cannot perform spontaneously under ambient conditions [39]. Fortunately, photocatalytic N2 fixation is currently at the forefront as one of the most attractive and meaningful alternative NH3 production method to the conventional Haber-Bosch reactions. This is because it does not use H2, but employs inexhaustible solar energy and water to directly provide N2 fixed active electrons and protons [40,41]. That is to say, NH3 can be synthesized directly from water and N2 under ambient conditions using sunlight as an energy source (N2 + 3H2O = 2NH3 + 3/2O2). Nevertheless, due to the weak interaction between the catalyst and the N2 molecule, the photo-generated electrons are not easily transferred from the catalyst to the N2 molecules. In addition, during this reduction process, some high-energy nitrogen intermediates (N2 − or N2H) are also formed, which makes the N2 fixation process more difficult than the hydrogen production and CO2 reduction. Consequently, the development of a high-performance cobalt based catalysts are much desired for artificial photosynthesis. In order to develop meaningful structure-activity relationships and thereby increase photocatalytic efficiencies and quantum yields, understanding of multiscale phenomena and principles relating photocatalyst composition with electronic structure, photoinduced charge diffusion with transfer, surface with interface reactions, catalyst coupling to form semiconductor heterojunctions, and reactor design all need to be understood to a reasonable level and thus synergistically optimized [42–44]. In the subsequent section, we will summarize recent research advances in the rational design and efficient synthesis of cobalt-based photocatalysts with controlled morphologies or crystallinity, heterojunction construction, crystal facet engineering, surface modification and other strategies, along with their applications in water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation. 3 Synthesis of cobalt based heterogeneous photocatalysts As we all known, it is undoubtedly that the design and synthesis of materials as holy grails in the field of photocatalysis, which is the initial step towards achieving high performance materials. Based on this, considering the success of boosting the photocatalytic performance of a single photocatalyst with coupling an appropriate catalyst, various high efficient strategies have been employed to fabricate cobalt based catalyst. That is to say, the activity of the photocatalytic system is highly dependent on the synthesis and anchoring route of the cobalt-based catalysts, which regulate the chemical and phase structure, surface morphology, facet distribution, and interfacial junction between them. On the one hand, according to the cobalt-based precursor’s phase, the two main fabrication strategies are solid-phase and solution-phase synthetic route (coprecipitation, sol-gel, template, hydro/solvothermal and other routes) [45,46]. On the other hand, it is widely accepted that the method of anchoring the catalyst over a semiconductor is very significant. There are two basic anchoring routes of cobalt-based catalysts (post loaded strategy and in situ reduction strategy) [47,48]. Some of these important synthesis methods will be introduced in the following corresponding sections. This allows in-depth understanding of the correlation between structures and their functional properties in order to encourage our research to control the synthesis of innovative energy cobalt based materials with tailored structures. 4 Application of cobalt-based heterogeneous photocatalysts Cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts have been demonstrated excellent performance in a wide range of photocatalytic applications, such as water splitting (including HER, OER and overall water splitting), CO2 reduction, N2 fixation, degradation of organic pollutants and other similar reactions [49–52]. In the last decade, many endeavors have been devoted to the development of cost-effective cobalt-based catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation reactions [53–57]. Cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts are mainly classified into these categories: nanoparticles and single atom, metal oxides, sulfides, phosphides, in addition to some new materials, such as the corresponding carbides, nitrides, and phosphides, which have been synthesized successfully for promoting the photocatalysis. The evaluation parameters of photocatalytic performance can be calculated according to the following equation (Eqs. (1)–(8)). Through a comprehensive and rational evaluation, the photocatalytic properties can be reasonably evaluated and compared. In this section, the photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation of cobalt-based photocatalysts are summarized as follows (in Table 2–4 ). (1) O 2 yield = moleofdetectedO 2 evolution moleoftheoraticO 2 evolution × 100 % = 2 × themolaramountofoxygenproduction themolaramountofNa 2 S 2 O 8 × 100 % ( Na 2 S 2 O 8 assacrificialelectronacceptor ) (2) TON = molesofevolvedproducts molesofactivecenteresofthecatalyst × 100 % (3) TOF = TON reactiontime × 100 % As for the selectivity of photocatalytic CO2 reduction, the main reduction products (such as CO, CH4, HCOOH and so on) come from the reduction reactions involved with different amounts of photogenerated electrons. The 2e reduction product CO and CH4 is an 8e reduction product, so the selectivity of different CO2 reduction products can be calculated with the following equations (herein, R represents the productive rates of products, the coefficient in front of R is the consumed electron number of multi-electron reactions): (4) Selectivity for CO% = 2R CO/(2R H2 + 2R CO + 8R CH4 + nR other) × 100% (5) Selectivity for CH4% = 8R CH4/(2R H2 + 2R CO + 8R CH4 + nR other) × 100% (6) Apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) (%) = Number of reacted electrons/Number of incident photons × 100% N incident = Pt/hν = IStλ/hc P is the light power (W), t is the illumination time (s), h is the Planck constant (6.626 × 10−34 J s), ν is light frequency (Hz), I is the light intensity (W cm−2), S is the irradiated area (cm2), λ is wavelength of monochromatic light (m), and c is the speed of light in free space (3.0 × 108 m s−1). (7) Solar to hydrogen (STH) efficiency (%) = energy of generated H2/solar energy irradiating the solution × 100% = (rH2 × ΔG 0)/(P sun × S) × 100% where r H2 is the H2 production rate in mmol s−1, ΔG 0 is the free energy of reaction (H2O → H2 + 1/2O2, 237 KJ mol−1), P sun is the power density of sunlight (mW cm−2), and S is the light of area (cm2). (8) Solar to ammonia (STA) efficiency (%) = Energy of generated NH3/Solar energy irradiating the solution × 100% = (nNH3 × ΔG 0)/(W × A × t) × 100% where ΔG is the Gibbs free energy for ammonia generation from water and N2 (339 kJ mol−1); n is the molar number of generated ammonia; W, A and t represent the incident light intensity, irradiation area and time, respectively. 4.1.1 Cobalt nanoparticles and single atom To satisfy the favorable energy synergy, loading Co nanoparticles (NPs) has been developed as an effective strategy to improve the catalytic efficiency of semiconductor, which promotes the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and affords the active sites for water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 reduction [58–61]. For example, Lou's group [62] constructed a hierarchical nanocages by supporting ultrathin ZnIn2S4 NSs on Co/NGC nanocages with embedded Co NPs surrounded by a few-layered NGC shell (Fig. 3(a) ). Such structural and compositional virtues can expedite charge separation and mobility, offering large surface area and abundant reactive sites, which exhibited outstanding H2 evolution activity (11270 µmol g−1 h−1) and high stability without engaging any cocatalyst (Figs. 3(b) and (c)). Very recently, they [63] successfully decorated isolated cobalt atoms onto W18O49 ultrathin nanowires via surface modification engineering strategy (Fig. 3(d)). The decorated Co atoms not only perform as the real active centers for efficient CO2 reduction but also work as the reaction switch for the reaction to proceed, yielding an impressive CO generation rate of 21.18 mmol g−1 h−1 using [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2·6H2O as photosensitizer (Fig. 3(e)). In another work, we [64] developed a cost-effective Co-NCNT (Co NPs decorated with nitrogen doped carbon nanotubes) through a facile pyrolysis process for HER and OER. It is the first time that Co NPs decorated with NCNT were employed as efficient bifunctional photocatalysts, which provides a novel strategy for expanding cost-effective water splitting catalysts. The results revealed that Co-NCNT-800 (pyrolysis at 800 °C) exhibited a considerable H2 evolution rate of 14.7 mmol g−1 h−1 and oxygen yield of 51%. Subsequently, we [65] rationally fabricated a novel nitrogen doped carbon layers coated Co NPs (Co@NC) as an efficient cocatalyst for photocatalytic H2 evolution via a one-step pyrolysis of the mixtures containing the simple cobalt salt and readily available carbon dots. The results revealed a high H2 evolution activity of 21.8 mmol g−1 h−1 for CdS with 3 wt% loading amount of Co@NC and 29.8 times higher than that of bare CdS, which was mainly ascribed to the effective electron transfer between the CdS and Co@NC. Very recently, Luo et al. [66] successfully synthesized MXene-based in-situ TiO2 with Co modified for photocatalytic N2 fixation by a two-step calcination method. Remarkably, the production of NH3 is as high as 110 μmol g−1 h−1 in pure water without using sacrificial agent under UV-vis light irradiation. The excellent performance is attributed to the introduced Co to adjust the adsorption energy of N2 and NH3 to achieve chemisorption equilibrium. Additionally, Xu et al. [67] employed H3PW12O40 (PW12) encapsulated with ZIF-67 as the precursor to synthesize N-doped graphitic carbon (NGC) nanocages hybrid loaded with WC and Co NPs (WC-Co/NGC) after calcinations (Fig. 4(a) ). Under visible light irradiation, the NH3 formation rate (142 μmol g−1 h−1) of WC/Co-NGC-2 was almost 6 times than that of Co-NGC with unloaded WC (Fig. 4(b)). The enhancement of photocatalytic N2 fixation effect was directly related to WC particle loading, together with the synergic effect between WC and Co. Meanwhile, 3D nanocages possessed a high specific surface and an appropriate location of the band structure, which obtained the efficient N2 fixation (Fig. 4(c)). It is composed of isolated metal atoms dispersed on the carrier and exhibit distinctly different catalytic behavior for metal NPs while simultaneously maximizing the per metal atom efficiency. In 2011, Zhang and co-workers [68] firstly proposed the concept of “single-atom catalysts (SACs)” and reported the practical fabrication of single Pt atoms supported on iron oxide nanocrystallites for both CO oxidation and preferential oxidation of CO in H2. Since then, a number of SACs (such as Pt, Pd, Ir, Ru, Au, Co, Fe, et al.) have gained significant attention, which become one of the most innovative and energetic scientific frontiers of research with outstanding performance in diverse catalysis. The uniform and stable SACs with high metal loadings (usually metal content of < 1 wt%) are highly desired, it nevertheless remains a great challenge in this field. The unique geometric and electronic properties of the developed Co-based single-atom catalysts can be assessed by using the multiple techniques of high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), Co 2p XPS, and Co K-edge x-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements. More importantly, Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) analysis can also afford useful information for the EPR-active Co(II) species. Infrared spectroscopy using CO as the probe molecule is another widely used technique to identify distinct Co species. Unlike the metallic cobalt, CoII 1O4 sites do not adsorb any CO at room temperature [69]. These applications and structure-performance relationships can provide theoretical guidance for the subsequent development of more stable and efficient cobalt-based single-atom catalysts [70]. In natural photosynthesis, porphyrin molecules have unique properties of sensing photons and transferring electrons, which has aroused extensive interest in the field of photocatalysis [71–78]. It is an effective implantation strategy to introduce single-atom metal species into porphyrin-based MOFs cavity for the catalytic applications. For example, Ye and co-workers [79] demonstrated that single Co atoms in the MOF-525 can greatly improve the electron-hole separation efficiency in porphyrin units by mechanistic investigation (Fig. 5(a) ). It was demonstrated that the photogenerated excitons migrated from porphyrin to catalytic Co center, thus providing long-lived electrons for the reduction of CO2 molecules adsorbed by Co center. In addition, As a result, MOF-525-Co obtained the highest CO evolution rate of 200.6 μmol g−1 h−1, and a CH4 evolution rate of 36.76 μmol g−1 h−1 under visible light driven, which was much higher than that of MOF-525-Zn and MOF-525 (Fig. 5(b)). There is no hydrogen was detected, indicating that the strategy effectively suppressing H2 evolution and thus increasing CO and CH4 selectivity. More recently, Jiang and co-workers [80] reported two COF-367-Co materials with different oxidation states of Co centered in the porphyrin (CoII and CoIII) by adjusting the cobalt salts of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O and CoCl2·6H2O, respectively. Interestingly, the oxidation state (+2 or +3) of the single-atom Co site significantly affected the spin state, which in turn leaded the electron distribution of the Co 3d orbitals and changed the interaction between Co and the reactant molecules. Therefore, the catalyst obtained higher activity and selectivity. In addition, DFT calculations indicated that CoIII in COF-367-CoIII favored the formation of HCOOH and possessed a much higher energy barrier for HCOOH conversion than COF-367-CoII. Thus, the COF-367-CoIII indicated favorable activity and remarkably enhanced selectivity for HCOOH rather than CO and CH4. The present work highlights the way for photocatalytic performance regulation by manipulating the spin state of catalytic metal centers, which is caused by the change in the charge microenvironment. There is highly desired to synthesize a uniform and stable SACs with high metal loadings, it nevertheless remains a great challenge. Based on this, Chen et al. [81] developed a new in situ fabrication strategy, which enabled the loading of the Co single-atoms on the nitrogen-enriched carbon framework (NC) with an enormously high content (up to 5.9 wt%). Thanks to the successful electron transfer from carbon nitride to the isolated Co SAs, it demonstrated their application as an efficient cocatalyst for photocatalytic H2 production with an evolution rate of 1180 μmol g−1 h−1 (Figs. 5(c) and (d)). Anchoring single metal atoms with suitable semiconductor substrates have received considerable attentions for the improvement in photocatalytic performance and its stability [82,83]. For instance, the CQDs doped with nitrogen have easily tunable bandgap and thus can act as photocatalysts. This advantage enables N-doped CQDs to function as an ideal photoresponse host for single metal atom catalysts. Thus, Li et al. [84] designed N-CDQs with surface anchored single Co atoms in a defined Co-N4 structure through facile pyrolysis of vitamin B12 (main porphyrin framework). In this system, the N-CQDs worked as both light-harvesting antenna and support for a high Co atom loading of 3.27 wt%, which acted as active sites with strong oxidative ability for water oxidation with oxygen evolution rates up to 168 μmol g−1 h−1. In 2018, Li and co-workers [85] reported the preparation of single atomic Co sites on C3N4 by a simple deposition method, which was the first example experimental work for photocatalytic CO2 reduction using single-cobalt(II) sites-catalysts without assistance of additional ligands. Extended X-ray absorption fine-structure spectra studies and photocatalysis clearly demonstrated the formation of single Co2+ sites and their important role in achieving excellent activity and product selective CO2 reduction. Very recently, a series of Co-C3N4 photocatalysts with different Co contents atomically dispersed on g-C3N4 were fabricated via a one-step calcination strategy of 2D cobalt-based MOFs and urea in the air [86]. The optimal 25-Co-C3N4 revealed excellent performance for photocatalytic CO2 reduction to CO, with a high CO evolution rate of 394.4 μmol g− h−1, over 80 times higher than that of bare g-C3N4, which benefited from the highly dispersed and rich exposed Co active sites, as well as good charge separation efficiency and abundant mesopores. In another work, Xiong and co-workers [87] reported a simple thermal treatment strategy to stably immobilize the isolated single Co atoms on the partially oxidized graphene nanosheets acting as a highly active and durable heterogeneous catalyst (Co1-G nanosheets) for photocatalytic CO2 conversion. Due to the straight forward metallic coordination situation, the turnover number (TON) for CO formation reached a high value of 678 with an unprecedented turnover frequency of 3.77 min−1 by using [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 as photosensitizer, superior to those obtained with the state-of-the-art heterogeneous photocatalysts. The above results indicated that the oxygen-containing functional groups on the graphene sheets can be employed as anchoring sites to immobilize single atomic metal sites. Subsequently, the researchers of the same group [88] successfully constructed a set of photocatalysts based on the 2D van der waals heterostructures by coupling g-C3N4 nanosheets with single cobalt sites (as the catalytically active sites) anchored reduced graphene oxide, which offered an ideal interface for efficient charge separation and transfer. As expected, the Co-rGO/C3N4 exhibited a remarkably enhanced photocatalytic syngas production with tunable CO/H2 ratio (from 1:30 to 2:3). In 2017, Wei et al. [89] demonstrated a strategy via constructing a cobalt single site to promote charge separation and surface reaction kinetics simultaneously for robust overall water splitting. These single Co atoms on phosphated C3N4 can form Co1-phosphide/PCN catalyst (Figs. 6(a) and (b) ). Thanks to the strong confinement of g-C3N4 and Co1-phosphide, it can simultaneously promote charge separation and catalytic activity with good stability over 24 h for robust overall water splitting and quantum efficiency up to 2.2% at 500 nm (Fig. 6(c)). The present work served as an excellent example exploiting the potential of ligated single atom site as a valuable component for efficient photocatalytic water splitting reaction. Similarly, Lu and coworkers [90] reported the photocatalytic H2 evolution properties of g-C3N4-based composite containing single Co1-N4 sites via an atomic layer deposition technique. The composite photocatalyst exhibited a robust H2 evolution rate reaching 10.8 μmol h−1, which was 11 times higher than that of pristine g-C3N4. All the cases discussed above involved both metal atoms and the supports, indicating the great potential of Co-SACs@substrates for efficient photocatalysis. Notably, as documented in literature, it can be proved that these strategies demonstrated a promising approach to improve energy conversion efficiency when used Co NPs or single atom as active sites. We believe that more and more excellent results will be reported in the near future. Recently, Fu et al. [91] employed a molecular scaffolding strategy to anchor and stabilize single-site cobalt on the porous crimped g-C3N4 (Co@g-C3N4), proposing as high-performance photocatalysts in solar-photon-driven N2 fixation under ambient conditions. As revealed in Fig. 7(a) , the bulk g-C3N4 revealed an extremely low and negligible N2 fixation activity of 8.2 µmol h−1, while the activity of g-C3N4 synthesized by supramolecular method was reached to 19.5 µmol h−1. After the incorporation of single cobalt sites, the optimal activity of Co@g-C3N4-1 was as high as 50.2 µmol h−1. Furthermore, there was no obvious deterioration after 3 cycles, demonstrating good stability toward harsh N2 fixation conditions under visible light irradiation (Fig. 7(b)). More importantly, DFT calculations conducted to identify the catalytically active sites theoretically. Interestingly, compared with bare g-C3N4, the coordinated cobalt site significantly became into the active center with strong adsorption energy of 0.99 eV (Figs. 7(c)and (d)). 4.1.2 Cobalt based oxides Considerable efforts have been devoted to design efficient and stable cobalt-based oxide photocatalysts for enhancing catalytic performance of water splitting and CO2 reduction, mainly including cobalt oxide (Co3O4) [92–97], cobalt hydroxide [Co(OH)2] [98,99], and cobalt oxyhydroxide [CoO(OH)]. It is a complex process to search empirical guidelines for the optimization of heterogeneous cobalt-based photocatalysts. It focuses not only on the type of catalyst, but also on other influential parameters, including crystallinity, morphology, size, exposed facets, surface vs. bulk oxidation states and other material properties [100]. In this section, we summarize and highlight some key approaches to modulate and optimize their surface atom arrangement and electronic structure of cobalt-based oxide photocatalysts, such as heterojunction configuration, structure and shape engineering, crystal facet tailoring, and mixed oxides [101]. In 2009, the pioneering work by Jiao and Frei’s group [102] presented a Co3O4 clusters in mesoporous silica for efficient water oxidation at mild conditions, whose TOF was more than 1000 s−1 under classical [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2/Na2S2O8 system. Notably, the TOF of the natural PSII was estimated at only 100 to 400 s−1 level in live cells and 1000 s−1 in vitro [103]. Just after one year, a study reported a stable carbon-free water oxidation catalyst (WOC) [Co4(H2O)2(PW9O34)2]10– (Co4PW9) for chemical water oxidation with [Ru(bpy)]3+, which achieved a TOF of 5 s−1 and TON of 78. Then, in 2011, the Co4PW9 was also used for light driven oxidation and reach a TON of > 220 [104,105]. Remarkably, in the same year, Stracke et al. [106] reported that this compound would release Co2+ ions to form CoO x as an active catalyst during electrocatalytic water oxidation. These results not only caused considerable interest in the field but also indicated the complexity of clear identification of the true active center. In order to clearly derive design guidelines for heterogeneous photocatalysts, the investigation of their reaction mechanisms is indispensable. Especially, true active sites and the pathways of the four-electron-transfer reaction still need in-depth investigations [50,107–109]. During photocatalytic cycles, the presence of high-valent active sites of first-row transition metal-based heterogeneous catalysts has been speculated by various characterization techniques, such as operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements [110], EPR analysis [111], transient absorption spectroscopy [112], and surface interrogation scanning electrochemical microscopy [113]. To render the discussion more concise, here Co3O4 is chosen as model systems. As all known, the spinel Co3O4 comprises of two kinds of cobalt ions, namely Co2+ in a tetrahedral coordination and Co3+ in an octahedral coordination. In 2014, Frei and co-workers [114] studied Co3O4 nanoclusters by using time-resolved FT-IR spectroscopy and isotope labelling experiments, which provided compelling insight into the two different roles of a surface superoxide intermediate (three-electron oxidation intermediate absorbing at 1013 cm−1) and a proposed Co(IV)=O intermediate (one-electron oxidation intermediate absorbing at 840 cm−1) in the water oxidation mechanism. The widely different photocatalytic efficiency of the two types of site is attributed to the presence/absence of adjacent Co(III)OH groups coupled via an oxygen bridge. For another example, Later on, Liu’s group [113] employed a cation-substitution strategy systematically to investigate the geometrical-site-dependent OER activity of Co3O4 catalyst by substituting Co2+ Td and Co3+ Oh with inactive Zn2+ and Al3+, respectively (Fig. 8(a) ). After a thorough in operando analysis by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and X-ray absorption spectroscopy, it was revealed that Co2+ Td site was responsible for the formation of CoOOH, which acted as the active site for water oxidation. This work provides a direction for the design of more effective light-driven catalyst for water oxidation. Recently, Maeda and coworkers [115] selected CoAl2O4 as a suitable efficient cocatalyst for water oxidation. Benefiting from the site selective occupation of Co2+ in spinel structure, it is different from a Co3O4 spinel that has both Co2+ and Co3+ at different crystallographic sites. The CoAl2O4 cocatalyst enhanced the water oxidation performance over the g-C3N4 photocatalyst by a factor of about 10 times and was also found to perform more efficiently than that of already well known Co3O4 and Co(OH)2 cocatalysts. Furthermore, according to the analysis of transient absorption spectroscopy, the CoAl2O4 cocatalyst with Co2+ as the main cobalt species at the A site of the spinel possessed better hole-capturing properties than the Co3O4, which was considered to be the main reason for the improved photocatalytic water oxidation. Furthermore, this work revealed that Al atoms, which does not essentially act as a cocatalyst component, can serve as an effective “diluter” to form a new cocatalyst material without loss of the original photoactivity of the Co3O4 (host) compound. Earth-abundant, low-cost light-harvesting semiconductors (such as TiO2, Ta3N5, BiVO4, g-C3N4) [99,116,117] with wide spectrum absorption could be used as alternatives to the classical [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 photosensitizers. For example, Xia and coworkers [118] fabricated a Co3O4 nanocrystal/carbon nitride nanofiber (COCNF) heterogeneous nanoplatform though a solvothermal method (Fig. 8(b)). The resulting COCNF demonstrated a significant enhancement of photocatalytic water oxidation with a high rate of 24.9 μmol h−1, which was 124 times higher than that of bare CNF. According to the experiment results and DFT calculations, the excellent water oxidation performance of COCNF was mainly due to the enhanced charge transfer, abundant oxygen vacancies, and exposed highly active crystal facet (222) induced by Co3O4 nanocrystals. In 2014, Bao’s group [119] demonstrated a visible light responsive nanocrystalline CoO, which was prepared by femtosecond laser ablation mechanical ball milling from CoO micropowders. More importantly, it exhibited a relatively high solar-to-hydrogen (STH) efficiency of 5% within 30 min for overall water splitting without the help of any cocatalysts or sacrificial agents. Nevertheless, the surfaces of CoO suffered from very quick photocorrosion or oxidation during the photocatalytic process (active for around 1 h). Recently, several effective strategies have been proposed to prohibit the rapid deactivation of CoO, including the optimization crystal structure as well as reasonable chemical composition, construction of a heterostructure, immobilization on support and introduction of a cocatalyst. For example, Kang’s group [120] attributed the poor stability of CoO to the carrier recombination-induced thermal oxidation. However, the issue of carrier recombination has not yet been settled for CoO itself. After that, they [121] formed another heterojunction of CDots/CoO which exhibited more-efficient visible light absorption than pristine CoO, leading to an outstanding overall water splitting photocatalytic activity and stability (over 15 cycles) (Figs. 8(c)–(e)). The H2(O2) generation rate for the optimized CDots/CoO was 1.67 μmol h−1 (0.91 μmol  h−1) with an expected 2:1 stoichiometry, six times as high as that of bare CoO. In addition, Yang et al. [122] reported that efficient solar overall water splitting into H2 (113.04 μmol  h−1) and O2 (53.76 μmol  h−1) with an expected 2:1 stoichiometry can be achieved by 2D amorphous CoO nanoflakes without using any cocatalysts or scavengers, and no deactivation was detected even after working for 120 h. Crystal phase engineering is another method to adjust the absorption ability in 2D ultrathin nanomaterials. Owing to the different atomic configurations of diverse crystal phases, the optical properties can be reasonably tuned. Xie’s group [123] fabricated tetrahedrally coordinated blende CoO atomic layers (denoted as B-CoO) and octahedrally coordinated rocksalt CoO atomic layers (denoted as R-CoO) with the same thickness. Based on the DFT calculations, the B-CoO displayed a smaller E g and abundant d-d internal transition features than those of R-CoO, suggesting that a broader spectrum range can be used and thus more charge carriers can be generated (Fig. 8(f)). As a result, the B-CoO exhibited boosted visible light driven overall water splitting with H2 and O2 evolution rates of 4.43 and 2.63 μmol g−1 h−1 (well-maintained during 24 h cycle tests), and the ratio of O2 to H2 was close to 1:2 which was roughly 3.7 times higher than those of the R-CoO sample (Fig. 8(g)). This work shows promise for achieving high efficiency overall water splitting. 4.1.2.1 Crystallinity controlling The above-mentioned discussed works have demonstrated that the high crystalline cobalt materials are employed as promising photocatalysts for improving photocatalytic activity and stability. In recent years, amorphous compounds have been triggered numerous attention due to their highly irregular structure and abundant unsaturated or defected atoms act as catalytic active sites [122,124–129]. As early as in 2014, Matthisal’s group [130] presented a facile solvothermal method to control the synthesis of CoFe2O4 (CIO-1) and amorphous CoFe2O n (n ∼3.66) (CIO-2) by controlling the crystallinity of the materials with changing solvent and reaction time for photocatalytic water oxidation. Notably, the amorphous CIO-2 exhibited superior catalytic activity over the crystalline CIO-1. As is known, syngas (a mixture of CO and H2) is a versatile fuel precursor for producing chemical and synthetic liquid fuels, and tunable CO/H2 ratios in syngas mixtures are the critical factors to meet the requirements of different industrial productions [131–133]. For this reason, Wang’s group [134] successfully designed amorphous novel-structured ultrathin CoO nanowires (UNWs) when selected polyoxometalate (Mo8) as an additive to further modulate the structure and crystallinity of CoO (Fig. 9(a) ). The results proved that the syngas production activity of amorphous CoO UNWs was obviously higher than those of larger size and higher crystallinity (Fig. 9(b)). Recently, our group [135] designed a CoO x coupled carbon dots (CDs@CoO x -300) as a bifunctional photocatalyst for efficient water oxidation and CO2 reduction by controlling the catalyst of crystallinity. Under the optimal conditions, the maximum O2 yield of 40.4% and high apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) of 58.6% were obtained over CDs@CoO x -300. Furthermore, the optimized sample of CDs@CoO x -300 also showed a CO selectivity of 89.3% and a CO generation rate of 8.1 μmol h−1. This work indicated that the spongy porous amorphous composite CDs@CoO x -300 can more effectively boost photocatalytic performances than those of high crystallinity catalysts. 4.1.2.2 Crystal facets engineering Apart from crystallinity of the catalysts, the crystal facets engineering of catalysts with the enhanced photocatalytic performance have also attracted remarkable attention [136–139]. For example, previous studies on shape-controlled Co3O4 have revealed that their catalytic performance closely associated with their crystal facet orientations on the structures/shapes [140]. Recently, our group [141] investigated three different morphologies (nanocubes, nanorods and nanosheets) spinel Co3O4 with different exposed facets for photocatalytic water oxidation (Fig. 9(c)). It was found that Co3O4 with {110} and {112} planes exhibited similar catalytic performance for water oxidation and their activities were clearly better than that of Co3O4 with {100} planes (Fig. 9(d)). As an excellent example, Tang’s group [142] synthesized an uniform Co3O4 hexagonal platelets (Co3O4 HPs) with controllable exposed (112) facets through a fast calcination strategy. The resulting Co3O4 HPs as excellent heterogeneous catalysts achieved a generation rate of 2003 μmol g−1 h−1 for photocatalytic CO2-to-CO conversion as well as a high CO selectivity of 77.1% (Figs. 10(c) and (d) ). The proposed mechanism for the photosensitized catalytic reduction of CO2 to CO was shown in Fig. 10(c). Moreover, on the basis of detailed experiments and DFT calculations, the exposed (112) facets of Co3O4 HPs exhibited much larger adsorption energy of CO2* (–1.69 eV) and smaller reduction free energy of CO2* to COOH* (0.32 eV) compared those of Co3O4 with (111) facets. These results demonstrated that the (112) facets of Co3O4 HPs favor the conversion of CO2* to COOH* and reduction to CO*, which was the first example about the facet effect of cobalt oxides to yield high activity and selectivity for photocatalytic CO2RR (Fig. 10(d)). 4.1.2.3 Mixed oxides Due to the redox properties, high chemical stability, rich optical and electronic features, recent works have also been invested that cobalt based mixed oxides as efficient catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting and CO2 reduction [143,144]. Replacing the partial Co in Co3O4 by other kind of elements (such as Mn, Cu, Fe and Ni) have been demonstrated as a practical method for improving the photocatalytic activity and stability. For example, M n Co3–n O4 (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) samples were synthesized through adding the bimetal sources, which exhibited high water oxidation activity under visible light irradiation [145,146]. Among the M n Co3–n O4 samples, Fe1.1Co1.9O4 nanorods were proven to be an optimal WOC [147]. The high water oxidation activity may be attributed to the substitution of Co2+ by Fe2+ that could facilitate the formation of O-O bond and improve the electron transfer efficiency during photocatalytic reaction. Photocatalytic water oxidation reaction in nature in photosynthesis is catalyzed by Mn4CaO5 clusters, which exhibit a cubic structure [148–152]. Inspired by the cubic structure of Mn3Ca oxides, Dissmucks’s group [153] developed two kinds of lithium cobalt oxides (cubic Li2Co2O4 and layered LiCoO2) to explore their dye-sensitized photocatalytic water oxidation behavior (Fig. 11(a) ). It revealed that only the cubic Li2Co2O4 possessed Co4O4 cubane structure, which is very similar to that of the Mn4CaO3 core in PSII. This made it active for catalyzing the oxidation of water. However, the layered LiCoO2 was not catalytically active. Subsequently, they [154] fabricated a Mg-substituted Co3O4 with 3D ordered mesoporous structure via a hard templating method. As the photocatalytic reaction goes on, the Mg in mesoporous Mg-Co3O4 was partially leached, resulting in an ultrahigh surface area (up to 250 m2 g−1) and a much higher oxygen evolution activity (TOF = 5 × 10−5 s−1 per Co atom or 5 × 10−4 s−1 per surface Co atom). The template method is a classic strategy to construct hollow structures. With appropriate hollow scaffolds as supports, 2D nanosheets as subunits grow on their surface [155,156]. Lou’s group [157] demonstrated the rational design and synthesis of hierarchical hollow nanostructures fabricated of ultrathin NiCo2O4 nanosheets and N-doped carbon (NC) nanoboxes for reduction of CO2 (Fig. 11(b)). Impressively, thanks to their unique structural and compositional merits, the hierarchical NC@NiCo2O4 photocatalyst exhibited outstanding photocatalytic CO2RR activity and high stability, achieving a high CO evolution rate of 26.2 mmol g−1 h−1 and apparent quantum yield (AQY) of 1.07% (Figs. 11(c) and (d)). The excellent photocatalytic performance of NC@NiCo2O4 was attributed to exposure rich Ni-Co redox active species and the highly conductive NC support, which was believed to reinforce CO2 adsorption and guarantee efficient charge separation and transfer. Very recently, they [158] explored a hierarchical assembly strategy to organize anisotropic prussian blue analog nanocrystals (PBA NCs) toward colloidal clusters (CCs) with open and highly ordered structures. Benefiting from the ordered multilevel porous structures, the obtained Co-Fe PBA CCs exhibited greatly enhanced catalytic activity for CO2 photoreduction, which the highest CO evolution rate reached as high as 14200 μmol g−1 h−1. Although most CO2 reduction studies are conducted in high purity CO2, in fact, the atmospheric CO2 in air, such as exhaust gases discharged from heavy industries, is relatively low (ca. 10%) [159,160]. In this regard, it is highly urgent to search for efficient photcatalysts to convert the low concentration of CO2 into multiple energy-rich chemicals. Therefore, Deng and Lin’s group [156,159,161] developed a series of cobalt based catalysts to overcome this issue. For example, they [156] reported an isostructural NiCo2O4 and MgCo2O4 hierarchical hollow nanocages (HCs) for diluted CO2 photoreduction. NiCo2O4 HCs achieved an AQY of 1.56% with CO selectivity of 89%. At present, excellent single function photcatalysts have been extensively explored to alleviate sluggish reaction kinetics. It is still challenging to design high performance bifunctional catalysts for simultaneously H2 production and water oxidation, which is vital to improve the artificial photocatalysis efficiency without any sacrificial agents. Most recently, Du et al. [162] designed and synthesized a non-stoichiometric nickel-cobalt double hydroxide via laser ablation (L-NiCo) in the liquid phase for photocatalytic overall water splitting, which exhibited a large band gap and features abundant exposed surface O2- and Co3+ ions (Figs. 11(e) and (f)). The large band gap enabled the photoexcitation of electrons and holes with enough energy for overall water splitting, while the O2– and Co3+ ions can serve as catalytic sites to boost HER and OER, respectively (Fig. 11(g)). This work was the first report on driving overall water splitting with a single-phase hydroxide, which represented a break-through in the direct conversion of solar energy into a hydrogen source. In the photocatalytic water oxidation system, apart from semiconductors coupled with cobalt oxide, there are still some cobalt based photocatalysts can play dual roles, which they act as both light absorption centers and water oxidation sites without any photosensitizer or cocatalyst [163–165]. For example, Wang et al. [163] investigated the photocatalytic water oxidation differences of the same Co@Co3O4 core-shell catalyst under [Ru(bpy)3]2+/S2O8 2–/light and S2O8 2–/light systems. In [Ru(bpy)3]2+/S2O8 2–/light system, both the catalyst and photosensitizer played important roles in OER, while the catalyst had bifunctional roles in S2O8 2–/light system: light absorb center and active catalytic site. From the above discussions, we can infer that that morphology, composition, crystal facets, and crystallinity in the cobalt based heterogeneous catalysts play significant roles in the photocatalysis, and thus enhancing photocatalytic activity. 4.1.3 Cobalt based sulfides Comparing to most metal oxide analogs, metal sulfides have attracted rising attention recent years as promising catalysts due to their unique optical and electrical properties [166,167]. In addition, the less positive VB occupied by S 3p orbital and small effective mass carriers, they have suitable energy band structure, wide photoresponse range and fast charge carrier dynamics, thus leading to the superior performance toward photocatalytic activity [168,169]. Especially, the rational coupling of cobalt-based sulfide with appropriate band semiconductors can effectively accelerate the separation and transfer of photoexcited charges due to the potential gradient between the heterogeneous interfaces. In this regard, abundant of cobalt based sulfide materials, as well as their hybrids and heterostructures, have been demonstrated as active photocatalysts for solar CO2 reduction and water splitting with positive achievements [170–174]. As mentioned above of photocatalysts, the hierarchical hollow structured photocatalysts with several intrinsic advantages have been attracted widespread attention for solar-to-chemical energy conversion. Specifically, the hierarchical hollow architectures can exhibit kinetically favorable open surface structure and short diffusion pathway for mass and charge transport, which can be beneficial for shortening the transmission distance of charge carriers [175]. Besides, these materials possess virtue of high specific surface areas and more accessible catalytic sites to accelerate reaction progress. More interestingly, the multiple reflections and scattering of light in the hollow structure can also enhance the utilization efficiency of solar energy. However, it is highly desirable but challenging to design and synthesize well-defined hierarchical structure with delicately controlled composition and morphology. An intriguing work found by Zhang and coworkers [176], they constructed the hierarchical CdS/Co9S8 nanoboxes as a Z-scheme heterojunction photocatalyst via a template-engaged multistep strategy for H2 generation (Fig. 12(a) ). In this system, the Co9S8 hollow cube was used as the electron donor semiconductor for the first time. Thanks to the Z-scheme heterojunction and the multiple reflections of solar light within the hollow cavity (Fig. 12(b)), the desired hierarchical hollow structure of CdS/Co9S8 nanoboxes significantly enhanced H2 evolution activity (1061 µmol g−1 h−1) and remained unchanged after 5 cycles compared to bare CdS, Co9S8 and solid CdS/Co9S8 particles. Besides, Lou’s group [177] recently reported another heterostructured cages, and they demonstrated the rational design and fabrication of hierarchical Co9S8@ZnIn2S4 as an efficient photocatalyst for hydrogen evolution (Fig. 13(a) ). The results exhibited the intimate interfacial contacts between the Co9S8 cage and ultrathin ZnIn2S4 nanosheets, which was highly favorable for efficient charge-separation/transfer in the hybrids. Consequently, the optimal Co9S8@ZnIn2S4 heterostructures can obtain a high hydrogen production rate of 6250 µmol g−1 h−1 and high stability without the aid of any cocatalysts. Apart from the nanoboxes structure, the study of tubular heterostructures has also been attracted great attention. For example, a unique Co9S8/ZnIn2S4 tubular heterostructures by Lu’s group [178] were successfully fabricated by growing 2D ZnIn2S4 nanosheets on 1D hollow Co9S8 nanotubes, The constructed Co9S8/ZnIn2S4 hierarchical hollow structures improved the light absorption ability and provided a large surface area as well as exposed rich catalytically reactive sites, which can effectively promote the separation and transfer of photogenerated electrons and holes (Fig. 13(b)). Ultimately, it exhibited a remarkable H2 generation rate of 9039 μmol g−1 h−1 without the use of any cocatalysts and possessed high stable after multiple photocatalytic cycles. Moreover, in 2017, we [179] fabricated a 3D hierarchical CoS acting as robust bifunctional photocatalyst with considerable H2 evolution rate of 1196 µmol g−1 h−1 (Eosin-Y as photosensitizer) and O2 yield of 63.5% ([Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 as photosensitizer) under visible light irradiation. The excellent photocatalytic performance was ascribed to the effective electron transfer between the photosensitizer and catalyst, which was verified by transient absorption experiments. In another work, through a solvothermal-ion exchange method, the spinel-type ternary metal sulfide NiCo2S4 was synthesized and firstly utilized as an efficient and stable catalyst for photocatalytic CO2RR with Ru[(bpy)3]Cl2 as photosensitizer under visible light, delivering a high CO liberating rate of 43.5 μmol mg−1 h−1 [180]. Designing band-new infrared light photocatalyst (ca. 50 % of solar spectrum) is highly imperative but remains challenging for photocatalytic performance [181]. Via a modified salt-mediated strategy, the ultrathin Ni-doped CoS2 nanosheets were fabricated for efficient CO2 reduction [182]. The TEM image of Ni-CoS2 (Fig. 14(a) ) manifested their ultrathin morphology. Notably, the evolution rate of CH4 over Ni-CoS2 was up to 101.8 μmol g−1 h−1, which was the highest record for IR-light-driven CO2 reduction among all single component photocatalysts (Fig. 14(b)). As shown in Fig. 14(c), both the higher desorption temperature of CO and lower desorption temperature of CH4 over Ni-CoS2 than those over CoS2, which were beneficial to further reduce the adsorbed CO into CH4. More importantly, in situ FTIR, DFT calculations and CH4-TPD showed that the doped Ni atoms in CoS2 could effectively depress the formation energy of the *COOH, *CHO and desorption energy of CH4 (Figs. 14(e) and 14(f)). Coupling of matched metal sulfides forming heterostructure is deemed as another effective method to boost their photocatalytic activity [177,183]. For example, Lou’s group [184] precisely integrated two metal sulfides into a hierarchical FeCoS2-CoS2 double-shelled nanotubes with both of the shells assembled from ultrathin 2D nanosheets. Benefiting from the distinctive structure and composition, the remarkable photocatalytic activity and high stability in a photosensitized system of CO2 reduction to CO (28.1 µmol h−1, per 0.5 mg of catalyst) for the FeCoS2-CoS2 hybrid were found to be better than that of FeSx-CoS2 nanotubes (17.7 µmol h−1) with [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 as photosensitizer and TOEA as sacrificial agent. The present work may inspire further development of metal sulfide semiconductors with ideal spatial nanostructures for artificial solar fuel production through CO2 reduction under visible light irradiation. 4.1.4 Cobalt based phosphides Transition based metal phosphides (TMPs), as efficient cocatalysts, become a popular alternative to precious metals in the field of photocatalysis with high electrical conductivity and chemical stability, and there are many ways to prepare them [185–189]. In General, according to the phase of reactants, the following two classical strategies have been applied for preparing TMPs. The first strategy can be obtained via a gas-solid reaction method. In this method, TMPs are easily formed by phosphating solid precursors such as metal oxides, hydroxides, MOFs, and some other compounds with highly reactive PH3, which is obtained by the decomposition of hypophosphites such as NH4H2PO2 and NaH2PO2 at high temperatures (over 250 °C) [190–192]. TMPs inherit the morphology and size of precursors to acquire the best photocatalytic activity performance. However, it should be noted that the highly toxic PH3 tail gas produced during this process needs to be handled with extreme care. Recently, hydrothermal/solvothermal method has been widely used for synthesis of TMPS as another mild method due to its high efficiency and simple experimental process. In this process, a homogeneous solution including phosphorous source (mainly white phosphorous, yellow phosphorous, red phosphorous, and black phosphorous), metal source, and solvent in a “one-pot” is transferred to the Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and then reacted at a specified temperature. The representative of the transition based metal phosphides is the cobalt-based phosphide. As a cocatalyst, the cobalt-based phosphide can adjust the energy band position of the main catalyst, change the transmission path of photogenerated carriers, and further improve the photocatalytic activity. Early in 2014, Sun’s group [193] first reported that CoP nanowires were active HER photocatalysts, which opened a new avenue for developing various cobalt phosphide-based materials as excellent catalysts for photocatalytic H2 evolution. Among them, CoP with the narrow band gap about 1.70 eV and appropriate energy band potentials was investigated mostly and a series of CoP-based photocatalysts were fabricated, such as CoP/Cd x Zn1‒x Se [194], CoP/BP [195], CoP/Zn0.5Cd0.5S [196], CoP/MIL-125-NH2 [197], CoP/CeVO4 [198], and CoP/TiO2 [199]. In addition to CoP, there are some other phases of cobalt phosphides including Co2P, CoP3 and amorphous CoxP have also attracted great attention. For instance, Chen et al. [200] for the first time found that Co2P NPs can be employed as an efficient cocatalyst for photocatalytic H2 evolution for a system containing CdS nanorods as a photocatalyst and DL-mandelic acid as an electron donor (Fig. 15(a) ). Under optimal conditions, the H2 production rate reached up to 19373 μmol g−1 h−1 after 10 h of LED light irradiation. Subsequently, they [201] reported a series of novel Mn0.2Cd0.8S/CoP3 composites, which were successfully prepared by loading CoP3 NPs on the surface of 1D Mn0.2Cd0.8S nanowires via a facile solvothermal method (Fig. 15(b)). Under visible light irradiation, the as-prepared Mn0.2Cd0.8S/CoP3 composite with 2.87 wt% of CoP3 displayed the highest photocatalytic H2 evolution activity with a corresponding H2 evolution rate of 29.53 mmol g−1 h−1 and an AQY of 29.2% at 420 nm, which was about 5.02 times higher than that of pure Mn0.2Cd0.8S and 1.79 times than that of Mn0.2Cd0.8S/Pt-1.5 wt%. Moreover, the Mn0.2Cd0.8S/CoP3 composite exhibited excellent photostability. The superior photocatalytic activity of Mn0.2Cd0.8S/CoP3 composite was predominantly attributed to the synergistic effects of highly efficient charge separation efficiency and sufficient active sites for H2 evolution reaction. Despite enhanced photocatalytic H2 production activity was achieved by introducing cobalt phosphides cocatalysts, there is still room for improvement. It has been demonstrated that the heterogeneous hybrid photocatalyst and mixed metal oxyphosphides with tailored structures could boost the photocatalytic performance. For example, a heterogeneous hybrid photocatalyst of Co and Co2P nanoparticles were embedded in carbon nanolayers co-doping with N and P (Co-Co2P@NPC) by a facile one-pot method [202]. This new mesoporous material of Co@Co2P@NPC as a catalyst and [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 as photosensitizer in a mixture of acetonitrile and H2O containing TEOA as a sacrificial agent were showed highly efficient visible light driven CO2-to-CO conversion (Fig. 15(c)), in which the average generation rate of produced CO was up to 35000 μmol g−1 h−1 with a selectivity of 79.1% in 3 h, comparing with Co@NC of 24600 and Co2P@NPC of 4300 μmol g−1 h−1. Compared with single metal phosphides, the mixed metal oxyphosphides with tailored structures and compositions can obtain higher selectivity and yield for photocatalysis. A multistep synthetic strategy was developed to modulate the chemical composition by Lou’s group [203]. They demonstrated the design and synthesis of highly dispersed nickel cobalt oxyphosphide NPs (NiCoOP NPs) confined in multichannel hollow carbon fibers (MHCFs) for efficient photocatalytic CO2RR under visible light irradiation. The NiCoOPNPs@MHCFs not only offered abundant catalytic active sites for redox catalysis but also effectively facilitated mass/charge transfer and enhanced CO2 adsorption. Ultimately, the optimized NiCoOPNPs@MHCFs catalyst manifested a considerable activity for CO evolution with 16.6 μmol h−1 when 0.1 mg of catalyst was used (Fig. 15(d)). This work may inspire more innovative works on the design and fabrication of mixed metal phosphide-based (Fig. 15(e)). To date, there are few researches reported about that cobalt based phosphides can catalyze water oxidation under visible light irradiation. For example, an abundant phosphorus vacancy was constructed in cobalt phosphide with reduced graphene oxide (R-CoP x /rGO) [204] for defect engineering to achieve efficient photocatalytic water oxidation (Fig. 15(f)). Despite this, its photocatalytic activity is not satisfactory, thus we [205] designed a CoP/NC nanocube catalyst through a pyrolysis phosphidation strategy derived from Co-Co prussian blue MOF-based precursor, which showed a high O2 yield of 36.1% and quantum yield of 61.5%. However, it should be noted that CoP/NC is not stable during photocatalysis, a unique CoP@CoO x core-shell structure was formed between the amorphous CoO x layer and CoP after visible light illumination. In addition, a novel core/shell cocatalyst with NiCoP as the core and NiCo-Pi as the shell was synthesized through a solid-state phosphorization reaction [206]. The core/shell NiCoP@NiCo-Pi could act as a bifunctional cocatalyst to boost the separate photocatalytic O2 and H2 evolution generation over g-C3N4 host photocatalysts (Fig. 15(g)). For the water oxidation half reaction, the Ni2+ and Co2+ ions in NiCo-Pi could capture photo-induced holes from the VB of g-C3N4 to form high-valence nickel and cobalt ions, which served as catalytic species for water oxidation. 4.1.5 Other cobalt based catalysts 4.1.5.1 Cobalt based MOFs Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are well-known crystalline materials constructed by metal ions/clusters interconnected with multi-dentate organic linkers [207–210]. Benefiting from their large surface areas, tailorable structures and high porosity, cobalt based MOFs have been attracted great attention in the field of photocatalysis. More importantly, open metal sites existed in MOFs can serve as both the absorption sites of CO2 or H2O molecules and active sites for photocatalysis [211,212]. For instance, Xu et al. [213] introduced the CoO x NPs of 2–3 nm into the zeotypic giant cavities of MIL-101(Cr) by a facile double solvent impregnation and heat treatment method (Fig. 16(a) ). This combination induced a highly efficient and stable in photocatalytic water oxidation activity with a high TOF of 0.012 s−1 per cobalt atom and oxygen yield of 88%, which is more than 9 fold compared with that of the unsupported Co3O4 NPs (Fig. 16(b)). In order to obtain efficient H2 evolution, dual cocatalysts can integrate the advantages of metals and metal oxides to achieve a competitive advantage over noble metals. Later, Ye’s group [214] utilized ultrathin 2D Co-based MOF (Co-MOF) nanosheets as specific precursors for preparing carbon matrix encapsulated dual cobalt active species (Co and CoO x ) on the surface of CdS (Fig. 17(a) ). The performance of CdS-Co-CoO x @C-450 achieved 1.997 mmol h−1 H2 generation with AQE of 43.7% at 420 nm evolution under visible-light irradiation (Fig. 17(b)). Recently, various kinds of halide perovskite materials have emerged as ideal candidates in the applications of solar-to-fuel conversions [215,216], For instance, Ding’s group [217] reported an uniform perovskite hydroxide CoSn(OH)6 nanocubes by a facile one-pot co-precipitation method and used for the first time as a non-precious-metal, highly efficient and stable photocatalysts, which promoted photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO under visible light irradiation. In addition, theoretical calculations showed that CoSn(OH)6 nanocubes could be capable of absorbing and activating CO2 molecules on the (100) surface and thus exhibited a high CO evolution rate of 18.7 μmol h−1. In another example, Chen et al. [218] reasonably designed and synthesized an in situ growth method to construct a CsPbBr3@ZIF-67 hybrid structure (Fig. 18 ). The halide CsPbBr3@ZIF photocatalysts exhibited improved charge separation efficiency, CO2 capturing ability, and moisture stability, which resulted in largely enhanced catalytic activity for CO2 reduction and yielded 2.66-fold more CH4 than pristine CsPbBr3. This work provided new insights for the design of excellent perovskite/MOF-based photocatalysts. As presented by Zhang, Liao and coworkers [219], a series of isostructural/isoreticular honeycomb-like MOFs (MAF-X27-Cl, MAF-X27-OH and MOF-74-Co) were synthesized for photocatalytic CO2-to-CO conversion (Fig. 19(a) ). Notably, they demonstrated that the TOFs of MAF-X27-Cl and MOF-74-Co decrease significantly by more than 90% when the CO2 partial pressure was reduced to 0.1 atm. In sharp contrast, under similar CO2 pressure, MAF-X27-OH gave a comparable TOF of 23 × 10−3 s−1 at 1 atm CO2 (Fig. 19(b)). Further DFT calculations revealed that the strong CO2 binding affinity of l-OH- ligands neighboring the cobalt center within MAF-X27-OH can stabilize the initial Co-CO2 adduct to promote the CO2 reduction, endowing an unchanged CO selectivity of 97.2% under low CO2 concentration. By utilizing a top-down fabrication process, Liu et al. [220] successfully synthesized and fully characterized a series of ZrIV-pyrogallic porphyrin MOFs, ZrPP-n-M (M = H2, Zn, Cu, Fe, Co, n = 1, 2). Among them, the representative ZrPP-1 demonstrated the strong chemical resistance under extreme harsh conditions upon immersion in saturated NaOH solution and in acidic media. Impressively, with precise and uniform distribution of active centers, ZrPP-1-Co, showed not only high CO2 trapping capability (≈90 cm3 g−1 at 1 atm, 273 K, among the highest in Zr-MOFs) but also high photocatalytic activity for reduction of CO2 into CO (≈14 μmol g−1 h−1) as well as high selectivity over CH4 (> 96.4%) without any cocatalyst under visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm). Furthermore, the present ZrPP-1-Co could be recovered and recycled for three rounds without obvious loss of morphological integrity and performance. According to the DFT calculation, a possible mechanism of photocatalytic CO2 reduction over porphyrin-MOFs was proposed. This work not only demonstrated a successful implementation of rational design of MOFs with noninterpenetrated isoreticular Zr-MOFs with the ever-expanding pore aperture but also represented a new robust platform for CO2-to-CO photoreduction by uniformly isolating active centers in metal-organic lattice. Very recently, Lin’s group [221] developed a flexible and controllable method to constructed ultrathin 2D holey Co3O4 nanosheets (Co3O4-NS) by air calcining of the ultrathin ZIF-67 nanosheet as templates. The as prepared 2D Co3O4-NS retained the porosity structure with high affinity to facilitate CO2 adsorption. Moreover, the Co3O4 monolayer (a thickness of approximately 1.8 nm) showed stronger CO2 adsorption energy than that of the bulk Co3O4 by DFT calculations. Ultimately, the photocatalytic activity performance for CO2-to-CO conversion over the Co3O4-NS reached a rate of 4.52 μmol h−1 with a high AQE value 0.71%, which is much higher than that of bulk Co3O4. Recently, Li et al. [222] employed a typical Co-ZIF-67 with network tetrahedral topologies to N2 on its porous structure, then combined with various POMs to supply multiple electrons for efficiently N2 reduction (Fig. 20(a) ). As a convincing result, ZIF-67@PMo4V8 exhibited the highest N2 fixation efficiency reaching 149.0 μmol L−1 at 1 h, and accompanying with the STA efficiency as high as 0.032% (Fig. 20(b)). Furthermore, the NH3 production is still very high compared to the first time reaction after five cycles. In another work, Wang’s group [223] reported four kinds of Dawson-type POM-based (P2W17M, M = Fe, Co, Ni and Mn) nitrogen vacancies graphitic carbon nitride (P2W17M@V-g-C3N4) hybrid materials, which exhibited excellent performance in the activation and subsequent dissociation of N2 molecules. Surprisingly, P2W17Co@V-g-C3N4 showed the best photocatalytic N2 fixation efficiency of 214.6 μmol L−1 h−1, which is mainly attributed to the rich defects of V-g-C3N4 and large specific surface area that can accurately and strongly adsorb N2 molecules. In addition, the doping of POMs has the advantage of increasing in light absorption to drive the reaction. 4.1.5.2 Cobalt based covalent organic frameworks As an emerging class of crystalline porous organic materials, covalent organic frameworks (COFs), especially two-dimensional COFs (2D-COFs), is versatile platforms offering new opportunities for flexible artificial photosynthesis in contrast to MOFs [224–228]. The well-designed structure together with synthetic diversity of 2D-COFs can be obtained large surface areas and readily tunable pore sizes, which not only facilitate the adsorption of CO2 molecules but also provide special microenvironments for the coordinated single metal center [161,229–232]. In order to manufacture 2D COF in large scale and high yield production, Jiang and coworkers [230] developed a scalable general bottom-up method to fabricate a series of uniform ultrathin (< 2.1 nm) imine-linked 2D COF nanosheets in large scale (> 100 mg) and high yield (> 55%), via an imine-exchange strategy through adding a large excess amount of 2,4,6-trimethylbenzaldehyde into the reaction system under solvothermal condition (Fig. 21(a) ). Specifically, visualization of the periodic pore lattice with a well-defined structure for COF-367 nanosheets by a scanning tunneling microscope can be clearly revealed the ultrathin 2D COF nature. Impressively, the COF-367-Co nanosheets as a new heterogeneous photocatalyst exhibited excellent photocatalytic activity toward CO2-to-CO conversion with a high CO selectivity of ca. 78% and production rate of 10162 μmol g−1 h−1 under visible light irradiation (Figs. 21(b) and (c)). The subsequent work can be used to construct 2D COF nanosheets coupled by other types of bonding linkages such as hydrazine and boronate ester for the further promising application (Fig. 21(d)). To overcome the prominent drawbacks of the lack of bare active metal centers over COFs, Lan’s group [233] reported a series of DQTP COF-M (M = Co/Ni/Zn) catalysts with a strong influence on the activity and selectivity of products (CO or HCOOH) for the first time (Fig. 22 ). Significantly, DQTP COF-Co showed a high CO production rate of 1.02 × 103 μmol h−1 g−1, while DQTP COF-Zn exhibited a high selectivity for (90% over CO) formic acid generation (152.5 μmol g−1 h−1, TON = 0.33 and TOF = 0.08 h−1). In addition, to illustrate the crucial role of the quinone oxygen atom for immobilizing the metal ions in DQTP COFs, the present work highlights the great potential of using stable 2D COFs as new platforms to anchor earth abundant metal active sites for efficient heterogeneous CO2RR. 4.1.5.3 Cobalt based Layered double hydroxides Introduction of Co element into the layered double hydroxides (LDHs) or hydrotalcites have considered as new class of promising low-cost catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting and CO2 reduction due to their easily controllable metal cation composition and mountable band structure [234–237]. It has been noted that LDHs act as efficient cocatalysts coupling with various semiconductors in the field of photocatalytic water splitting for O2 and H2 generation [209,238–241]. In 2014, Kang et al. [242] reported that CoFe LDHs as highly efficient photocatalysts exhibited different water oxidation abilities with different ratios of transition metals under visible light irradiation (Figs. 23(a) and (b) ). In addition, the UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra showed that the peak at approximately 500 nm corresponds to metal-to-metal charge-transfer and results in efficient water oxidation (Fig. 23(c)). As for photocatalytic H2 generation, a facile, eco-friendly and scalable strategy combining P-doping and in-situ loading NiCo-LDH to synthesize an efficient hybrid photocatalyst of NiCo-LDH/P-CdS was proposed by Ge’s group [243]. The as-prepared 2 mol% NiCo-LDH/40 wt% P-CdS photocatalyst exhibited a high visible light catalytic H2 generation rate of 8.665 mmol g−1 h−1, which was 45 folds higher than that of bare CdS. It indicated that the rational construction of heterojunction not only promoted the photogenerated charges separation, but also inhibited the photocorrosion of CdS (Fig. 23(d)). In 2011, Izumi’s group [244] employed Zn-Cu-M (iii) (M = Al, Ga) LDHs materials for photocatalytic CO2 reduction for the first time. Since then, LDHs have attracted more and more attention in CO2 photocatalytic reduction. For instance, Lin’s group [245] delicately achieved a novel 3D hierarchical Co-Co LDHs with conductive Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets (Co-Co LDH/TNS) nanoarray via an in-situ MOF-derived strategy, which can significantly accelerate separation of photogenerated charge carriers and promote electrons transmission (Fig. 23(e)). Benefitting from these features, the present hierarchical Co-Co LDH/TNS hybrids indicated evidently enhancement on the CO2-to-CO generating rate of 1.25 × 104 μmol g−1 h−1 with a high AQE of 0.92% and superb stability under illumination, with 2.2 times yield of CO compared with bare Co-Co LDH. This work opens a novel avenue for constructing MXenes-based 3D nanoarrays for improved photocatalytic CO2RR. Exploring photocatalysts with higher wavelength response (λ ≥ 650 nm) is challenging and crucial to further industrial application [246–248]. In view of that, through a facile one-step coprecipitation method, Song’s group [249] fabricated an efficient 650 nm-induced CO2 photocatalytic reduction system to syngas by introducing Co into MgAl-LDH (CoMgAl-LDH) nanosheets (Fig. 23(f)). Importantly, up to 650 nm, the as-prepared CoMgAl-LDH nanosheets exhibited catalytic activity with CO evolution rate of 0.35 μmol h−1 and quantum yield of 0.86%, which greatly improved the utilization of solar energy (Fig. 23(g)). As evidenced by XAFS and high-resolution synchrotron XRD, the dispersed Co active sites and appropriate band structure well-matched with [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 were beneficial to the efficient transfer of photo-generated electrons to boost the reaction. This work may provide an efficient strategy for CO2RR to syngas to facilitate the photocatalyst response of the visible-near infrared light region. 4.1.5.4 Cobalt based carbide Transition-metal carbide (TMC) has been emerged as a new type of cocatalyst for H2 production from water with outstanding electronic conductivity, chemical stability, and physical properties [250–252]. Under the guidance of DFT calculations, the photocatalytic H2 evolution of colloidal CdSe QDs [253], successfully assembled on the layered Co2C nanoflakes with preferred facet exposure, can be dramatically improved to give an ∼10-fold enhancement of the activity (Figs. 24(a)–(d)). Recently, Gao and coworkers [254] used Co3C as a noble-metal-free cocatalyst on CdS nanorods, which achieved highly efficient photocatalytic H2 production rate of 315 μmol h−1 (Fig. 24(e) ). Here, Co3C not only enhanced the activity of CdS but also increased the stability by suppressing the photocorrosion process (Fig. 24(f)). The further results successfully demonstrated that Co3C has the ability to play a positive role as a universal cocatalyst for photocatalytic H2 production when ZnIn2S4 and g-C3N4 nanosheets were employed as photosensitizers. However, cobalt carbide has not been investigated as a cocatalyst for photocatalytic water oxidation and CO2 reduction. Hence, it is of vital significance to explore the economical and promising cobalt carbide cocatalyst based on its unique excellent properties. 4.1.5.5 Cobalt based nitride Cobalt-based nitride has been proven to be an efficient catalyst for photocatalytic applications due to their close to metal properties and excellent electrical conductivity interface and thus improve photocatalytic activity [255]. Du et al. [256] reported that Co3N as robust and low-cost cocatalyst over CdS nanorods for enhanced photocatalytic H2 production reached 137.33 μmol g−1 h−1 and AQY was 14.9% at 450 nm (Fig. 24(g)). Afterwards, Li et al. [257] successfully decorated Co3N NPs on Zn0.5Cd0.5S, which obtained a H2 evolution rate (218.8 mmol g−1 h−1) under visible light irradiation and the AQY of 30.2% at 420 nm. Very recently, a new Mn0.2Cd0.8S/CoN composite photocatalyst was prepared through a simple electrostatic self-assembly strategy by Jin’s group [258]. The introduction of CoN can greatly enhance the H2 production rate of photocatalyst up to 14.6 mmol g−1 h−1, which was 17.3 times that of bare Mn0.2Cd0.8S (Fig. 24(h)). Benefiting from the lower CB of CoN and its excellent electron-conductivity, we can conclude that the cocatalyst CoN not only can effectively promote the separation of photogenerated electron hole pairs in semiconductor, but also form a tight metal-semiconductor. Another type of Co2N has been applied as a novel cocatalyst to boost photocatalytic CO2 reduction by combining with BiOBr ultrathin nanosheets [259]. Due to the effective charge separation and unique surface configuration of Co2N, the strong electronic interactions can be built to steer the electron transfer from BiOBr to Co2N. Ultimately, the optimal Co2N/BiOBr hybrid materials delivered a high selectivity CO generation rate up to of 67.8 µmol g−1 h−1 in pure water without adding sacrificial reagent or extra photosensitizer. More importantly, the Co2N/BiOBr hybrid can simultaneously oxide H2O into O2 with an average O2 evolution rates of 31.7 µmol g−1 h−1, with the CO:O2 ratio approach to the stoichiometric ratio of 2.
