Furthermore, the activation energy barrier can be lowered on the Co2N surface via stabilize COOH* intermediates, tuning the rate-limiting step from the formation of COOH* over BiOBr to the formation of CO* on Co2N, jointly optimizing the CO2 photoreduction activity. As demonstrated by XAFS spectra, DFT calculation, and ultrafast transient absorption spectra, the photogenerated electrons from BiOBr could be well transferred across the interface to Co2N due to the formation of strong electronic interactions. This is a excellent example that have been exhibited to be effective in suppressing H2 evolution. However, some activity of Co2N/BiOBr decreased after a 24 h reaction, hindering the potential industrial applications. 5 Conclusions and perspective In brief, this review mainly focuses on the latest achievements in cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation. Despite the encouraging progress so far, we recognize that the applications of cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts in such photocatalytic fields are still in the early stage and further developments are evidently required. Hence, it drives us to explore more rational design and development of cobalt-based heterogeneous photocatalysts to further cater to the practical demands in industry and our lives. Here, there are some challenges and perspectives are discussed in the following aspects. (1) Based on the high correlation between the material structure and photocatalytic performance (structure-activity relationships), it is undoubtedly that the design and synthesis of materials is holy grail in the field of photocatalysis. There are some regulating strategies which have been explored to optimize the performance of photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation, including morphology or crystallinity controlling, doping, crystal facet engineering, surface modification and other strategies. Through these wise strategies, the light absorption and the separation efficiency of photogenerated electrons and holes can be effectively improved, and the surface properties can also be adjusted, thus greatly enhanced the photocatalytic performance of cobalt-based photocatalysts (Table 2–4). There is still much room for improvement. Hence, in the following research, the great potential represented by the reactive site engineering to strengthen ability of surface catalysis for the multi-electron redox reaction with water, CO2, and N2 molecules, which it would be extensively concerned by researchers to further probe the intrinsic mechanism during the light driven process. Especially, the construction of atomic-level sites involves the defect sites, single-atom and surface functional groups, which will be a smart choice to achieve high efficiency utilization of charge carriers and motivated synthesis of reaction product. (2) According to the review of literatures, sacrificial agents have been frequently added into the reaction system to consume the photogenerated holes or electron, thus increasing the survival time of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and enhancing the photocatalytic activity. However, it should be emphasized that water splitting, CO2 reduction or N2 fixation reaction in the presence of sacrificial agents can only be considered as a “partial solar fuel”. Therefore, as the ultimate goal in sustainable energy research, it should be focused more on exploring alternative ways to achieve overall photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation without using sacrificial agents and external bias. (3) Urgent and important issue that the inconsistency of photocatalytic performance tests need to be addressed, including the different usage amounts of photocatalysts, sacrificial reagents, the different types of catalysts, and light sources. In addition, the preparation of the catalyst should be scaled up to reach the industrial fuels and value-added chemicals production level, such as reactor size, light source dispersion and catalyst recovery. Specifically, in most cases, the NH3 yields are low and rare consideration is given to the effect of interference on NH3 quantification. Hence, the advantages and disadvantages of these detection methods for NH3 quantification (Nessler’s reagent method, indophenol blue method, and ion chromatography method) should be carefully considered [260]. Furthermore, it is important to properly evaluate the AQY, STH, STA and selectivity of photocatalysts for understanding the intrinsic nature of a photocatalyst related to light harvesting, photogenerated charge separation and transfer, and surface catalytic reactions. Thus, standardization of photocatalytic performance tests is highly desired [261, 262]. (4) In order to precisely understand the catalytic mechanism and design more efficient photocatalyts, the fundamental studies on these cobalt-based catalysts are essential. More importantly, advanced characterization techniques, such as synchrotron radiation, time-resolved spectroscopy, in situ/operando infrared, raman and electron spin resonance spectroscopy, and aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy and theoretical calculations should be comprehensively implemented. Therefore, the interfacial charge dynamics and real reaction mechanism between cobalt-based photocatalysts and light-harvesting materials could be come true. In summary, with an eye to the future, a great number of opportunities and challenges are presented for this booming and hot field. We hope that this review could provide some references and perspectives for cobalt based photocatalysts with high activity, stability and visible-light utilization efficiency for water splitting, converting CO2 and N2 into high fuels and value-added chemicals. In the end, we look forward to more exciting developments of cobalt-based materials for efficient photocatalysis. Yong Ding received his Ph.D. degree in Physical Chemistry from Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, in 2005. Then, he joined the College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Lanzhou University. In 2009, he went to Emory University as a visiting scholar. When he returned back Lanzhou University in 2011, he was promoted to a full professor. He is now the director of the institute of physical chemistry of Lanzhou University and is Feitian scholar distinguished professor of Gansu Province. He joined the editorial board of Chinese Journal of Catalysis in 2020 and Chinese Chemical Letters in 2021. He has published about 130 peer-reviewed papers in primary SCI journals and gave about 50 invited lectures at various scientific conferences so far. Ding’s main research interests are as follows: 1) Artificial photosynthesis; 2) Water splitting by polyoxometalates, metal complexes and metal oxides; 3) Photocatalytic conversion of carbon dioxide; 4) Synthesis, characterization and catalytic applications of polyoxometalates.

coredata.dc:description: Solar-driven conversion of carbon dioxide, water and nitrogen into high value-added fuels (e.g. H2, CO, CH4, CH3OH, NH3 and so on) is regarded as an environmental-friendly and ideal route for relieving the greenhouse gas effect and countering energy crisis, which is an attractive and challenging topic. Hence, various types of photocatalysts have been developed successively to meet the requirements of these photocatalysis. Among them, cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts emerge as one of the most promising photocatalysts that open up alluring vistas in the field of solar-to-fuels conversion, which can effectively enhance photocatalytic efficiency by extending light absorption range, promoting charge separation, providing active sites, and lowering reaction barrier. In this review, we first present the working principles of cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts for photocatalytic water splitting, CO2 reduction, and N2 fixation. Second, five efficient strategies including surface modification, morphology modulation, crystallinity controlling, crystal engineering and doping, are discussed for improving the photocatalytic performance with different types cobalt-based catalysts (cobalt nanoparticles and single atom, oxides, sulfides, phosphides, MOFs, COFs, LDHs, carbide, and nitrides). Third, we outline the applications for the state-of-the-art photocatalytic CO2 reduction and water splitting, and nitrogen fixation over cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts. Finally, the central challenges and possible improvements of cobalt-based photocatalysis in the future are presented. The purpose of this review is to summarize the past experience and lessons, and provide reference for the further development of cobalt-based photocatalysis technology.
